introduction.p: Nearing the end of this section, we have now discussed several tranformations which can be performed on a function. Since we now have a solid grasp on each of these transformations, let's apply multiple transformations to a function and study the outcome.

subsection.title: Order Matters
subsection.p: In the previous section we looked at the image below where f(x)=(x-1)^2. yHorizontal Compression Note that since f(x)=(x-1)^2, the function x^2 shifted to the right by 1 . As we know from the last section, f(2x) is a horizontal compression by a factor of 2 .

Thus, the function f(2x)=(2x-1)^2 is the result of starting with x^2 and applying
horizontal shift right by 1
horizontal compression by a factor of 2
in this order.
Now, what happens if we start with x^2 and start with a horizontal compression by a factor of 2 (shown below in red) and then apply a horizontal shift right by 1 (shown below in blue).
Comparing the two results (in both pictures the final stage is in blue) it is clear that the order in which the transformations are performed is very important.

subsection.title: Which Order to Use
subsection.p: As discussed thus far, in general, the order is important with transformations. However, if the transformations are vertical and horizontal changes then it does not matter whether the horizontal or vertical transformations are handled first. In general, we can follow the following guide:

assemblage.title: Order of Transformations
assemblage.p: Suppose that f(x) is our function we are applying transformations to. Once written in the form a\cdot f(b\cdot (x+h))+k the order of transformations is:

ol.li: horizontal stretch or compress by a factor of \abs{b} or \abs{\dfrac{1}{b}} (if b\lt 0 then also reflect about y-axis)
vertically stretch or compress by a factor of \abs{a} or \abs{\dfrac{1}{a}} (if a\lt 0 then also reflect about x-axis)

statement.p: Describe the function 5\cdot [f(-3x-6)-1] as a list of transformations done to f(x) in the appropriate order.
